Award.AwardTitle: Tropical Intraseasonal Variability in Models and Observations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Work conducted under this project seeks to determine the underlying mechanisms responsible for the development and propagation of the Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO), a large-scale pattern of precipitation and atmospheric circulation anomalies which forms in the Indian Ocean and propagates slowly eastward. The MJO is associated with droughts, floods, and tropical cyclones (including hurricanes in the Gulf of Mexico). The research is primarily organized around experiments using an atmospheric general circulation model which has been modified to produce credible MJO simulations. The work will be guided by the hypothesis that the MJO is a moisture mode which is destabilized by wind-evaporation feedback (occurring under westerly wind conditions), which propagates eastward through horizontal moisture advection, and in which the essential dynamics are regulated by the processes that control the tropical moisture field. The modeling work is complemented by analysis of wind and precipitation from moored buoys in the Indian Ocean and satellite observations.

The work will have broader impacts due to the large societal impacts of the MJO and the practical utility of information which contributes to the development of a predictive understanding of the MJO. The project will also include graduate student training and postdoctoral support, thereby developing the next generation of scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding how and why heavy and organized tropical precipitation occurs is one of the greatest challenges in the tropical meteorology field today. Our lack of understanding limits not only our ability to simulate and predict tropical weather such as hurricanes and intense tropical downpours that affect parts of the Gulf Coast and Atlantic Coasts, but it also affects our ability to forecast weather across the United States, since what happens in the tropics has far-reaching affects across the rest of the globe. This dependence is demonstrated strongly during times such as this year when El Nino in the tropical Pacific is influencing weather across the globe in places such as the United States. Our NSF project was designed to foster improved understanding and simulations of a particular type of organized tropical precipitation called the Madden-Julian oscillation, or MJO for short. The MJO is a large region (e.g. size of Australia) of organized precipitation that moves eastward across the tropics and causes the weather to shift from rainy to dry to rainy again every 40 days. The MJO affects extreme hurricane activity (such as Hurricane Katrina), U.S. West Coast flooding events, drought, and heat waves and cold spells across the United States. Weather forecasting and climate models have traditionally had trouble simulating this phenomenon. Our project has forged a much deeper understanding of the MJO, and has provided guidance on how our forecasting and climate models need to be modified to produce better simulations, which is critical for predicting extreme events that can affect life and property across the United States. In particular, the following outcomes have resulted from this successful project, which are documented in the 25 peer reviewed studies to result from this grant:

 

1) We have demonstrated using models and observations that the interaction of tropical precipitating systems with atmospheric radiation is critical to producing the MJO. Buoys observations in the Indian and west Pacific oceans also suggest that surface evaporation caused by gusty winds is also important for supporting these precipitating systems. This information provides guidance on what aspects of forecast and climate models need improvement to produce better forecasts.

 

2) We have shown that making precipitation in forecasting and climate models more strongly dependent on atmospheric moisture makes for better predictions and simulations of the MJO, enabling skillful forecasts out to 4 weeks in advance. This provides further guidance to model developers on how to make better weather and climate forecasts.

 

3) We have demonstrated that movement of moisture caused by the winds is the primary reason for why the MJO moves toward the east.

 

4) We have developed a hurricane prediction model for the east Pacific and Atlantic Oceans that use El Nino, the MJO, and the annual cycle as model inputs. This model produces skillful hurricane predictions for the Gulf of Mexico, Atlantic, and east Pacific oceans at lead times of 3 weeks or greater.

 

5) We have demonstrated that changes in MJO strength in future climate appear to be very sensitive to the exact pattern of changes in ocean temperature. Since the pattern of ocean temperature change in future climate is highly uncertain and varies strongly from climate model to climate model, this suggests that much uncertainty exists in how tropical precipitation will change in future climate.

 

6) Two postdoctoral researchers, 4 graduate students, and 4 undergraduate students have participated in this project in some form, supporting the training of the next generation of atmospheric science researchers.
